abstract: Cyberspace allows us to digest information in bite-sized nuggets. But an author ponders the effect of all this mental hopscotching on our ability to read books and engage in sustained thought.
snippet: Cyberspace allows us to digest information in bite-sized nuggets. But an author ponders the effect of all this mental hopscotching on our ability to read books and engage in sustained thought.
lead_paragraph: The cover story of this month’s Atlantic Magazine has a provocative piece by Nicholas Carr, called “Is Google Making Us Stupid?” Mr. Carr got my attention with this comment:

abstract: Yahoo‘s chief executive, Jerry Yang, made the rounds on Capital Hill on Wednesday, in an effort to dispel antitrust concerns surrounding its search advertising deal with Google.
lead_paragraph: Yahoo‘s chief executive, Jerry Yang, made the rounds on Capital Hill on Wednesday, in an effort to dispel antitrust concerns surrounding its search advertising deal with Google.

headline.main: Yang Goes to Capitol Hill to Talk Up Google Deal

abstract: The more people who leave Yahoo, the less stable it becomes, leading to more questions about its leadership, less new business, delayed products and still more departures.
snippet: The more people who leave Yahoo, the less stable it becomes, leading to more questions about its leadership, less new business, delayed products and still more departures.
lead_paragraph: In trying to buy Yahoo, Microsoft had a clear goal: To be No. 2 to Google in search and advertising. If things keep going the way they are heading, it may well achieve that goal without spending the $50 billion Yahoo would have cost.

headline.main: Has Microsoft Sent Yahoo Into a Death Spiral?
